#269 Use G1 and add basic memory limits

Use G1 and add basic memory limits

Empirically G1 was found to put the least load on the system on the three boxes tested.
Memory usage between 250m and 800m.
CPU usage hovers around 9% of one core on my test machines VS 30 with previous values.

make it easier to opt out of Java 7-compatible builds

We need Java 7-compatible builds for releases, but there have been a few occasions where people have wanted to contribute, but have had difficulty creating a local build because of our setup requiring a JDK7 classpath.

This commit makes 2 changes:

- Instead of checking the nil-ness of `(System/getenv "JDK7_BOOTCLASSPATH")`, it checks whether it's nil or empty string (via `clojure.core/empty?`). I think on some systems, it might be empty string (not nil) when not set.

- Before, when JDK7_BOOTCLASSPATH was not set, it would not include the -bootclasspath JVM option, but would still include the -source 1.7 and -target 1.7 options. Now it leaves all three out, so you can make a non-Java 7 build if you want, for convenience when developing.

make server stateless (remove stateful commands)

Prior to this commit, the server was responsible for not only handling requests, but also holding a score in memory and appending/replacing it or providing info about it based on the clients' commands.

Commands based on this state included:

- alda play (without a file or string of code -- plays the score in memory)
- alda play --append
- alda score
- alda info

This commit removes these commands (and associated code) from the client and removes the stateful parts of the server, so that the server only has to worry about starting an Alda environment (loading MIDI synth pool) and responding to one-off requests to play or parse a score.

The next step will be to offload the "work" (having an open MIDI synth, parsing and playing scores) onto separate worker processes and having the server just be a broker between the client and the workers.

With this type of architecture, it is not really feasible for the server or the workers to keep track of a "current score" for the client, so the user will have to do this manually. I think this is actually a better pattern, because people who use computers are already used to managing documents as files and running command-line programs as one-off things that don't manage state for us.

I think my original intent was for the Alda client/server experience to be just like the Alda REPL experience, which was an interesting experiment, but unnecessary I think. If users want the REPL experience, they can always use the REPL.

simplify variable getting/setting

This simplification makes variable getting/setting a whole lot easier to understand and reason about. Instead of tracking the environment of a variable at the time it is defined and then referencing it later, we just look through the variable's events and go ahead and dereference any get-variable events that might be in there. This ensures that no defined variable will contain a "get-variable" event. Scope is no longer an issue -- we just use the current scope at the time the variable is defined.

With this change, things basically work exactly the same as before, but now the Alda score map contains a single key `:env` instead of a complicated, nested `:variables` map and a temporary `:env` to track the current scope.

I suspect that if we ever need to make this more complicated (e.g. first class functions/closures), we can leverage Clojure functions instead of reimplementing scope... it seems like we don't need to reimplement scope as part of the Alda score evaluation state machine.

optimize music-data rule

Per @aengelberg:

This takes some thought to fully verify it's doing the right thing. My reasoning is:

* With `!calls`, we guarantee a new part is not starting at the current character.
* A `part` always starts with a `name` which would begin with at least two letters.
* Thus, we can safely eat all of the next letters in a row, because if a part started after some but not all of the next letters, those letters would have to be part of the part name. Hence `[a-zA-Z]*`.
* Now, we can safely eat all of the next non-letters in a row (i.e. numbers, special characters, and whitespace), because a part may not start at the current point or in between any of those non-letters. Hence `[^a-zA-Z]*`.
* At this point, we can now eat any letter not followed by another letter without having to re-check for `!calls`, because an acceptable-name starts with at least two letters in a row. So we finish the regex off with `([a-zA-Z][^a-zA-Z]+)*`.

use a regex to parse non-comments faster

Before this change, non-comments were getting parsed one character at a time, which was significantly slower.

Credit: @aengelberg

oops, clojure 1.7.0 was still in dependencies

No idea what the impact of this might be, but it can't be good. We should just be using Clojure 1.8.0.

don't let durations end with a slur

This prevents ambiguity where either a note's last duration ends with a slur or the note itself ends with a slur.

After thinking about it, I realized that a duration (at least one that can be considered "slurred") never exists in an Alda score unless it's associated with a note, so we don't really need durations to include a slur. (Other things can have durations too, like cram expressions, but those can't be slurred, so it's probably for the best that we not allow them to be slurred.)

don't allow durations to end with a barline

Removes ambiguity between scenarios where a note's duration contains a final barline vs. there being a barline after the note.

make header and part rules greedily consume newlines

There was ambiguity where the header and part rules may or may not end with newlines. This fixes that by having the header and part rules greedily consume any newlines.

bugfix: don't let attributes be applied more than once

Now attributes are only applied right before a note or rest event happens. Before this commit, there was one other place that attributes were applied -- at the end of the score. I was initially thinking that would be good so that the current "state" of the instrument at the end of the score reflects any attribute changes that may happen at the very end of the score. However, the attributes would then be applied again once the score is continued, leading to problems for attributes whose values
depend on the current attribute value (e.g. octave up/down).

fix buggy attribute behavior

Attributes were either being applied too few or too many times. This fixes that.
pre-initialize a pool of MIDI synths

adjust alda.sound to handle isolated scores

This changes all of the alda.sound functions to accept an "audio context" atom, which references a Clojure map whose values include mutable things that do the work needed to bring music to your eardrums -- things like the MIDI Synthesizer and the JSyn SynthesisEngine. The audio context also includes score-specific information like which audio types have been initialized, and the mapping of instrument IDs to MIDI channels in the MIDI synth being used for that score.

Luckily, in testing this locally, there don't seem to be any obvious performance issues so far -- it appears that multiple MIDI synthesizers and multiple SynthesisEngines can coexist peacefully -- which is awesome. We'll see if this causes problems in the long run.

One issue is that it takes a second or two for a new MIDI synthesizer to initialize. Whereas before, this was a one-time cost paid when alda.sound was evaluated, now it happens every time a new score is created and the MIDI audio type is set up. There is a mechanism for setting it up ahead of time via the `set-up!` function, but it's still not great that you have to wait a second or two every time you start a new score. I have an idea for fixing that that I think will work -- set up a pool of MIDI synths that have already been initialized in background threads, and draw from the pool each time a fresh synth is needed. There could perhaps be a supervisor thread that monitors the number of available MIDI synths and spins up new ones as needed. It would be good to handle stopping the MIDI synths after we don't need them any more... not sure how to approach that just yet. Maybe just provide a way to do it on demand (I guess there already is a way -- the tear-down! function) and have the REPL and server do it whenever you start a new score or load an existing one.

updated alda.now to use alda.lisp the new way

With the changes I just made to alda.lisp, score evaluation is now a self-contained process. This allows us to be flexible in the way we use alda.now.

I've adjusted things so that the `play!` function by default will start up a new score and evaluate the events in its body within that context. It actually uses *current-score* as the context, but when that's nil, it starts a new score and uses that.

Scores are represented as atoms referencing Alda score maps.

*current-score* can be manipulated via the `with-score` and `with-new-score` macros, which bind *current-score* to a particular score or a new score, respectively, and then both modify *current-score* and return the modified score.

There's also `play-score!`, which will play an entire score, given the score map or an atom referencing it.

only set timbre level in alda.lisp

This is the only real place we need to call alda.util/set-timbre-level!, which defaults the logging level to :warn if it isn't already set in the environment.

Typically things that use Alda (and thus may include logging) will require alda.lisp, so the logging level will get set at that point.

functionally purify alda.lisp

Lots of changes and refactorings here. I think I might write a blog post about it.

To briefly summarize this commit:

  - BEFORE:
    - There were a bunch of top-level dynamic vars like *current-instruments* and *events* and a bunch of others.
    - We were alter-var-root'ing and binding'ing things all over the place.
    - Because of this, only one score evaluation context could exist at a time; loading a new score into a server, for example, would necessarily have to interact with or overrwrite any existing score evaluation context. One-off evaluation of a score (without affecting the current score in progress) was not possible.
    - Score evaluation relied on mutable state over time as the score got evaluated. For example, evaluating (note (pitch :c)) would alter-var-root on *events* and *instruments* to update the state of those things.

  - AFTER:
    - No more top-level vars.
    - A score is a map containing a bunch of data about the current state of the evaluation context. Because immutable data is awesome, the current state of a score can easily be stored in a symbol or an atom or be let-bound or whatever.
    - This makes it easy to evaluate multiple scores (with different evaluation contexts) at the same time, and each score evaluation context is a totally isolated environment.
    - This will make it possible for the server to parse, evaluate and play Alda scores in isolation from one another, solving many bugs and generally making life easier.
    - Incidentally, fixed issue #199. Local attributes occurring at the same time as global attributes will now override the global attributes.
    - alda.lisp event functions like `note` and `chord` no longer work via side effects. Instead, each event function returns a map containing all the necessary information about that event.
    - The score function basically reduces through the events of the score, starting with a fresh score context map and updating it for each event in the score.
    - There is a function called `continue` which will take a score context map and continue evaluating further events. This is what we're going to use to "update" a score a little at a time via the Alda REPL, server and command-line client.
    - Because event functions no longer work via side effects, inline Clojure code will work a little differently. Basically, you'll just write code that returns one or more Alda events, instead of code that produces side effects and returns nil.
add task to generate completions.cson for language-alda

load/save score evaluation context

This sets it up so that the values of all the score evaluation context dynamic vars (now quarantined in alda.lisp.score.context) can be saved and loaded programmatically. The `score` macro now saves the previous score evaluation context, evaluates its body with a fresh score evaluation context, then loads back the previous context when it's done.

un-mix alda.lisp namespaces

Get rid of the (in-ns 'alda.lisp) monkey business. Instead, explicitly define things in their own namespaces, and refer to them from other namespaces. It's more sane this way.

In the process of doing this, I was forced to resolve some circular dependencies by moving some things into their own "lower-level" namespaces.

We still want most of the public vars in all of these namespaces to be available in one convenient place (alda.lisp), so use potemkin's `import-vars` to refer them all in.

Merge pull request #177 from alda-lang/bugfix-voice-parsing

bugfix re: voice parsing

bugfix re: voice parsing

In some cases, voice parsing wasn't happening correctly -- subsequent voices were being nested inside of the previous voice, instead of them all being nested at the same level in the voice group like they should be. This was caused by an ambiguous grammar rule that allowed a voice group to be an event in a voice. Alda doesn't support nesting voices inside of voices, so we can solve the ambiguity by disallowing that explicitly.

1.0.0-rc1

don't write target dir (not needed in this case)

The `bin` and `exe` tasks write binary executables to an output dir specified as an option to the `build` task, and this happens separately from writing to the target dir, so we don't really need to use the `target` task here, which might save a little time during builds.

When we do want the target dir written to, we can just add `target` on the end of the task we're running on the command-line.

load FluidR3 when `stock` option not included

This also includes a change to the way we're holding a reference to the FluidR3 soundfont. Trying to get the soundbank from the same InputStream more than once results in an error "cannot get soundbank from stream." The workaround here is to only get the soundbank once, then store that in *midi-soundbank*. The `load-fluid-r3!` function checks to see if *midi-soundbank* is already loaded (non-nil), and iff it is not, it fetches FluidR3 and loads it into *midi-soundbank*.

This change makes it so that you can start the server and/or repl multiple times in a Clojure REPL while developing.
kill off alda.cli, move logic into alda.server, alda.repl

server: rm play, parse and script tasks

With a dedicated client, we'll be moving away from having a CLI interface for the server at all. All interaction will be client -> server. Will probably end up moving the "repl" and "server" entrypoints into their own namespaces, and have the client call them directly, then scrap the alda.cli namespace altogether.

(The "repl" will eventually be ported to the client and just be another way to interact with a server.)

Initial Java rewrite of client

Ended up scrapping the Go client once I realized that I could package the whole project (server & client) into a single uberjar, with a Java client entrypoint that doesn't load the Clojure back-end until necessary. Java is also way more battle-tested than Go, and I think will make for easier cross-platform compatibility.

Initial Go implementation of client

This commit also includes some server changes/improvements that came about while developing the client.

avoid printf

When running the project from an uberjar, you have to explicitly `(flush)` output after you `printf`. Using `println` instead makes it easier to avoid this.

Merge pull request #146 from alda-lang/refactor-parser

Improve parser

update tests

Previously, `test-parse` was used for all the parser tests to attempt to parse each syntax example as that rule, e.g. `(test-parse :cram "{c c c}")`. The implementation relied on our previous single-grammar parser, parsing from a given start rule. This is no longer possible, but we do have a general-purpose `parse-with-context` function which can attempt to parse arbitrary input as music-data. This is actually better for tests because we're not telling the parser which
rule to use -- we're just handing it some code and saying "parse this as music data," and testing that it parses as the right thing.
merge parse-with-start-rule and parse-with-context into a single fn with multiple arities

update parsing smoke tests

Now that there are multiple parsing steps, Alda's parser cannot return a single instaparse failure object like it did before. Instead, it throws an exception as soon as one of the parsing steps fails.
there is no longer a single parse tree

Extract parser into separate tasks :scissors:

This commit changes Alda's parsing process from using a single, monolithic grammar to parse an entire score in one pass, to parsing a score in several discrete steps, using a separate grammar/parser for each phase.

The perks of doing it this way:

- It will give us greater flexibility with syntax features. For example, this will make it a lot easier (maybe even possible to begin with) to implement inline variable definitions which terminate in a newline -- we can just parse them after comments and Clojure expressions, but before everything else.
- We can leverage more of Instaparse's built-in optimizations for parallelizing work. Each instrument part will be parsed concurrently, for example.
- Because we'll be feeding each parser smaller bodies of text, performance will improve significantly. I tested at least one score that took ~6 seconds to parse before, but now takes ~600-700 ms.

The downsides:

- There is no longer a single parse tree for an entire score.
- Parsing errors will be harder to understand from the stacktrace alone. Line/column numbers will no longer refer to the entire score file, but rather the small section of the score that is being parsed.
- We'll need to rewrite/rethink `parse-with-context`, which the Alda REPL uses to determine the context of a snippet of Alda code. Currently this works by doing a series of partial parses using the single alda.bnf grammar.

I think these are hardships worth enduring for the benefits we'll gain, especially in light of the poor performance we're dealing with with the current single-grammar system, and the need to pave the way forward for advanced syntactical features as the language's grammar grows in complexity.

bugfix: don't allow negative note lengths

Due to a recent change to the grammar, "-" is being included in note lengths instead of being parsed as a flat, causing weird behavior with code like "cello: b-8" because it things -8 is a note-length. This fixes that by disallowing negative numbers to be parsed as note-lengths.

downsize deps :chart_with_downwards_trend:

@jeluard noted that we have `overtone` as a dependency but we're only using `overtone/at-at`, and also that we have `reply` as a dependency but we're not really using it at all :)

It turns out that we were passively using `reply` in that it pulls in JLine, from which we are using the ConsoleReader in alda.repl. We may as well just pull in `jline`, though, instead of `reply` with all its dependencies.

0.10.3: fix edge case bug introduced by 0.10.2 :bug:

bugfix: make playback start immediately

There is a bug here that causes playback to always start at offset 0, rather than the earliest offset out of the event set. I think the intent here is to make sure that the offset is at least 0, but we still want it to be the earliest offset from the event set, as long as it's a positive number (which it should be anyway... but it doesn't hurt to have a safety net!).

asynchronous playback!

(it was already asynchronous, I just made it so that the Thread/sleep x length of the score is optional; the Thread/sleep is only really necessary for the `boot play` task, which needs to block so that the process doesn't exit)

always use a new MIDI channel for each instrument

Initially I was trying to save channels (since there are only 16) by doubling up on channels when there are two instances of the same MIDI instrument.

However, while transcribing the prelude to Bach's first cello suite I ended up needing to create a second cello instance (which was made to share a MIDI channel with the first one) for the overlapping 'A' pedal tone notes alternating between the open A string and unison 'A' note on the D string, and I discovered that the MIDI note-off events for that 'A' were clobbering those of the other part.

Having two instances of an instrument share a MIDI channel is clearly asking for trouble. From now on, one MIDI instrument (instance) = one MIDI channel.

move CLI syntax from wiki; alda.repl spec

re-organizing, preparing for new audio types :boom: :notes:

This does a bunch of things:

- Adds "midi-note" field to Notes. Since the MIDI note was already being calculated in the process of determining the frequency in Hz, converting it back to the MIDI note number didn't really make sense. This should also make it easier to see at a glance the MIDI number of a note.

- Extends the Offset protocol to java.lang.Number (prevents unexpected errors)

- Big thing #1: moves the more generic aspects of alda.sound.midi/play! to alda.sound -- aspects such as setting up the audio environment and scheduling note events. Now each audio type (MIDI, sampled, synth, etc.) essentially only needs to define 3 things: set-up actions, tear-down actions, and the play-event! method. alda.sound will take care of setting up the environment based on the types of audio present and scheduling and playing the events.

- Big thing #2: sets up alda.repl to build up a score incrementally and parse and play lines of code within the context of said score. Before, it was parsing each line as a new score, evaluating and playing it. Now the score evolves with each line of code you add. Repeatedly referring to the same instrument actually adds to the events for that specific instrument, not a new instrument in a new score. I've started defining methods called parse-within-context and play-within-context that will act differently depending on what part of the score you're in. The prompt should also change to reflect the context. For example, if you enter "piano: c d e" in the console, the context should change to :music-data for the piano, the prompt will look something like this: "piano> " and any subsequent lines can just be, e.g. "f g a b > c" and will be evaluated within the context of a piano part. We may be able to extend this concept to voices as well -- have the prompt show e.g. "piano(V1)>", then "piano(V2)>" etc. until you break out of the voices by switching to a new instrument or calling V0. There's still some work to do here, but I've set up the framework and for the time being, the context is always :part, so each line has to consist of an instrument call ("piano: ") and some music data.

alda.repl is fast now! :rocket:

It turns out that the slowness was just the result of opening a new MIDI synth every time a new score is evaluated. The parsing process actually happens almost instantaneously. So now, the Alda REPL opens one MIDI synth initially and uses it to play the score generated by each line.

One-off playing of Alda code/files from the command-line is still pretty slow, but that's probably a JVM startup time issue.
REPL getting better - using jline.console.ConsoleReader now

very beginnings of alda.repl (much work needed!)

* Many features yet to be implemented. Right now it just plays back each line as a new score, ignoring any previous context. Evaluating a score as we go along would be better. I have so many features planned.

* It's so slow! There is probably a lot of overhead associated with evaluating each line as a new score -- we should probably be creating one MIDI synth at the beginning and reusing it.

* This is sort of a naïve way to make a REPL. Would probably be better to use clojure-lanterna or something, and properly handle arrow keys, ^C, etc.

fix part creation & corresponding tests

Aliasing instrument names (e.g. piano, trumpet) to MIDI instruments (e.g. midi-acoustic-grand-piano, midi-trumpet) illuminated a bug where existing instruments weren't being recognized because it was looking at the stock instrument rather than the actual "name" of the instrument. For example, calling a part called "piano" would initialize a midi-acoustic-grand-piano, but then subsequently calling "piano" again would look for something with the stock instrument "piano," not find it, and decide to initialize a new midi-acoustic-grand-piano instead. The "name" of the instrument is stored in its id, so now the part-assigning function looks at the beginning of the id string (+ a hyphen) to determine if an instrument already exists. Tests pass now. :+1:

fix bug preventing awobmolg.alda from eval-ing at the CLI

The Alda score evaluator was throwing an error about not being able to resolve the symbol $current-offset, when trying to do "boot parse --map -f test/examples/awobmolg.alda". Interestingly, I was still able to evaluate the score from the REPL within the alda.lisp namespace. The problem ended up being in alda.lisp/chord*, a macro that was generating a literal symbol '$current-offset, which was only eval-able within the alda.lisp namespace. Fully qualifying the symbol (`$current-offset) fixed it. :+1:
